DataElement.preferredDefinition: Type of cancer genetic test offered or taken.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Evaluation of an individual's DNA to look for a genetic alteration that may indicate an increased risk for developing cancer.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The probability that exposure to some agent or substance will adversely transform cells to replicate and form a malignant tumor. (EPA Terminology Reference System)

Concepts.definition: The probability that exposure to some agent or substance will adversely transform cells to replicate and form a malignant tumor. (EPA Terminology Reference System)

Property.preferredDefinition: Analyzing DNA to look for a genetic alteration that may indicate an increased risk for developing a specific disease or disorder.

Concepts.definition: The process of isolating and testing the DNA of an embryo or a person to detect the presence of genetic alterations or defects that may predispose to the future development of a disease or disorder.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary)

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Analyzing DNA to look for a genetic alteration that may indicate an increased risk for developing a specific disease or disorder._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

PermissibleValues.value: A test for other cancer genes

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Analyzing DNA to look for a genetic alteration that may indicate an increased risk for developing a specific disease or disorder.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
The process of isolating and testing the DNA of an embryo or a person to detect the presence of genetic alterations or defects that may predispose to the future development of a disease or disorder.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The answer is not known by the person answering.

Concepts.definition: The answer is not known by the person answering.

PermissibleValues.value: A test for breast cancer genes

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.: Analyzing DNA to look for a genetic alteration that may indicate an increased risk for developing a specific disease or disorder.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.
The process of isolating and testing the DNA of an embryo or a person to detect the presence of genetic alterations or defects that may predispose to the future development of a disease or disorder.

PermissibleValues.value: A test for colon cancer genes

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor usually arising from the epithelium lining the large intestinal mucosa.  Colon carcinoma is one of the most common malignancies in both males and females, and is especially common in North America and Europe.  Grossly, most colon carcinomas are polypoid or ulcerating lesions. Microscopically, adenocarcinoma is the most frequently seen morphologic subtype.  Prognosis depends on the stage of the disease (depth of invasion, metastasis to regional/distal lymph nodes or other anatomic sites). -- 2004: Analyzing DNA to look for a genetic alteration that may indicate an increased risk for developing a specific disease or disorder.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm that arises from the colon and invades through the muscularis mucosa into the submucosa.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas.
The process of isolating and testing the DNA of an embryo or a person to detect the presence of genetic alterations or defects that may predispose to the future development of a disease or disorder.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).
